instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] Orange light No fan spin - Getting 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[PLAIN][SOLVED] [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] Orange light No fan spin - Getting 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>[/PLAIN]

Hello everyone, i got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power. I was able to find to find a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>. <CAPACITOR>C7324</CAPACITOR> was the culprit. After re-checking my voltages I noticed that I'm only getting 1.03v instead of 8.6v in this line. Any idea what's causing this? Is <CAPACITOR>C7324</CAPACITOR> required to produce 8.6v? I haven't replaced it yet. Thanks for the input

PPBUS G3H 8.57v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 1.03v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v

threads.title: [SOLVED] [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] Orange light No fan spin - Getting 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The short probably has blown the fuse! F7000 or 7100, well you know what I mean.

threads.title: [SOLVED] [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] Orange light No fan spin - Getting 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: F7140 was blown. After replacement, we got a spinning fan :)
